repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Essential Public Health
            Functions and Programs Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Essential Public Health
            Functions and Programs Project for Argentina were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: financing public health functions
            instead of vertical programs (HIV/AIDS, immunization, etc.)
            allows for the improvement of the delivery of vertical
            programs while strengthening health systems overall. In
            federal settings where provinces have a large degree of
            autonomy, the signing of 5-year umbrella agreements between
            federal and state levels outlining each party's
            responsibilities protects against political risk. The
            inclusion of an emergency contingency component in
            investment operations is an effective approach to address
            emergencies. Realistic risk assessment regarding
            implementation capacity will ensure the needed support is
            built into project design. Project evaluation methodologies
            need to be defined during preparation to ensure the needed
            information is available. The Governance and Accountability
            Action Plan (GAAP) provides a common fiduciary tool to
            address overall systemic accountability issues. Its joint
            design with the Government will increase ownership and
            effectiveness. In addition, agreed supervision plan and
            regular close supervision by the Bank's fiduciary team
            has substantially reduced implementation risk since its introduction.

Argentina - Essential Public Health

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Essential Public Health
            Functions and Programs Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Essential Public
            Health Functions and Programs Project (FESP) for Argentina
            are to increase the coverage of ten prioritized Public
            Health Programs; reduce population's exposure to
            principal risk factors associated with collective illness;
            and improve the stewardship role and appropriate regulatory
            environment of the Nation's public health system. The
            purposes of the restructuring are: (i) to modify three
            project development indicators, (ii) to reallocate loan
            proceeds; and (iii) to extend the project closing date by 12
            months from December 31, 2011 to December 31, 2012. The
            Project FESP is financed by a US$220 million loan that was
            approved by the Board of Executive Directors of the World
            Bank on November 21, 2006 and has been effective since
            September 6, 2007. To date the Project has disbursed
            US$184.66 million, with a remaining undisbursed balance of
            US$35.21 million. The targets of three out of six Project
            Development Objective (PDO) indicators were fully achieved
            in 2010. These include the following: (i) measles
            eradication; (ii) congenital rubella eradication; and (iii)
            reduction of tobacco prevalence among the population of 18
            to 64 years old. Progress with these indicators reflects the
            Borrower's intensive work on epidemiological
            surveillance of vaccines and tobacco control, both of which
            have been supported by the Project through a Public Health
            Activities (PHA) output based mechanism. The Project has
            made significant progress in Public Health Activities
            implementation. In 2010, implementation of PHAs increased by
            almost 100 percent as compared with the cumulative amount
            PHAs executed in the last three years of the Project.
            Progress made demonstrates that management by results is now
            accepted by the provinces as an effective instrument for the
            implementation of public policies.

7999235.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Essential Public Health
            Functions and Programs Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Essential Public Health Functions
            and Programs Project for Argentina aims to increase the
            coverage of ten prioritized Public Health Programs; reduce
            the population's exposure to principal risk factors
            associated with collective illness; and improve the
            stewardship role and appropriate regulatory environment of
            the nation's public health system. The project
            components are: 1: The activities financed by this component
            seek to improve capacity at the national and provincial
            level to carry out the essential public health functions
            that are at the core of health stewardship and necessary for
            the success of key public health programs. This component is
            divided into two subcomponents, one geared to strengthen
            functions at the national level and the other at the
            provincial level. 2: Activities financed by this component
            seek to i) improve efficiency and equity of the provision of
            medical supplies necessary for the success of priority
            public health programs; and ii) contribute to a rapid and
            organized response from the health sector in the case of a
            health emergency. This component is divided into two
            subcomponents: to strengthen inputs management and
            performance monitoring for priority public health programs,
            and to improve preparedness and response to a potential
            Avian Influenza epidemic, and other health emergencies and
            natural disasters. 3: Activities to be financed under this
            component will aim to provide supervision and monitoring of
            Project implementation, to ensure its transparency, and to
            create positive externalities in the area of governance
            applicable to the whole health sector.
